{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3167178,"name":"Allison Conrad","username":"scubadiv3r","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scubadiv3r/{size}/234274_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-18T01:01:18.713Z","cooked":"

Hey all, weâ€™re trying to convert our pneumatic pistons to linear servos and are running into a weird situation. Seems like after a few seconds of holding the cone up, they just give up even when still receiving signal.

These two servos are connected up directly to the RoboRIO right now, and while I would love to just use a REV Servo Power Module I donâ€™t have time to get one. Iâ€™ve hooked up servos like the drawing below for personal projects before, Iâ€™m just trying to assess if this would be an allowable option in FRC, combed over the rules again and Iâ€™m not confident in an answer

IMG_35931920Ã—1440 141 KB

R505:

R505 *Control servos safely. Servos must be connected to, and only to, 1 of the following:
A. PWM ports on the roboRIO,
B. PWM ports on a WCP Spartan Sensor Board (P/N WCP-0045), or
C. REV Robotics Servo Power Module (P/N REV-11-1144).

Your voltage regulator is not on that list.

The real problem is probably inherent to the servo, not a power supply issue. When you stall the motor inside the servo, it gets hot. Pretty fast. When it heats up, its resistance increases, decreasing the current flow, decreasing the torque. You may be better off going to one of the smaller wormgear automotive motors which wonâ€™t backdrive, so you donâ€™t need to keep current flowing.

Could you double the count, splitting the load on each?

There are two right now, theyâ€™re basically setup as a linkage with the 1x1â€™s seen in the gif so they donâ€™t take all the force if they get hit. We set them up for speed to open that door quickly, so it may very well be a poor application issue here

We use servos to grip our cone /cube see picture below, we use programmable servos that allow us more flexibility with there overload protection, as well as the power percentage applied to them, you can also dictate the position you want it the default to if signal is lost

I would look into programmable servos, itâ€™s very tough to find a set that still falls under the $75 dollar rule though.
is also worth noting the possibility of camming over the servos into a lock position this is what we do with our cone so that the clamping force is even greater then what the servos would typically provide being driven
the image below is the cam Over position we are no longer driving the servos at this position, and itâ€™s applies significant force onto the cone with minimal wear and tear in the servos

image828Ã—1792 3.34 MB
